title: Engineers Drove a Car With Digital Brakes a Staggering 2,000 Miles in 6 Days-and Survived
text:
Bosch drove a care equipped with its bold brake-by-wire system for 2,000 miles in 6 days—and survived. Here's how the bold technology works. Bosch made its bones building reliable, best-in-class power tools. But you might not know that the German brand has also had a mobility division for over a century, developing industry-leading braking and steering systems. Now, Bosch's latest invention, brake-by-wire, eliminates the "mechanical" connections from the brake pedal to the brakes.
If that gives you pause, brake-by-wire testing is working—so far—on public roads. Bosch's development team, based in Abstatt, Germany, recently took the technology onto the open road using a Nissan Ariya (modified with Bosch brake-by-wire) to tackle a 2,050-mile, six-day road trip from southern Germany to the brand's winter test center in northern Sweden.
"With our first long-distance test, we impressively demonstrated that we can bring a real brake-by-wire system safely and successfully from the track to the road," Hagen Kuckert, the project manager for the by-wire brake actuator, said in a recent Bosch press release.
Automakers have taken notice of brake-by-wire benefits, as Bosch has reportedly received multiple orders already. The technology will officially launch this fall, with the German brand forecasting 5.5 million vehicles to be equipped with brake-by-wire by 2030.
What Is Brake-by-Wire?
Ph. Courtesy Bosch
There's a misnomer that "digital" braking is a wireless system with zero physical connection. Bosch markets its system as brake-by-wire, meaning there's a wire connecting the brake pedal to an electronic controller instead of a hydraulic hose coupled to a brake caliper. This means the system's logic doesn't change that much—or at all. Pressing the brake pedal sends an electronic signal to the braking system instead of sending hydraulic fluid.…
